rev.diff:
Line 183: Line 183:
==== 2 February ====
==== 2 February ====
â
{{Copy edit|section|date=February 2011}}
+
[[File:AngerRevolution.png|thumb|Forward to victory]]
â
At noon local time, internet access in Egypt has been at least partially restored and the night-time curfew in Egypt has been eased. It will now run from 5:00 pm to 7:00 am the next day instead of 3:00 pm to 8:00 am.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12307698 |title=BBC News - Egypt unrest |publisher=BBC News |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Curfew hours were shortened to 5:00 pm to 7:00 am the next day.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/>
  â
;Clashes
+
During the night of 1â2 February, Mubarak supporters and anti-Mubarak protesters clashed in Alexandria; shots were reportedly fired in the air.<ref name="aljazbloglive">{{Cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/01/live-blog-feb-2-egypt-protests |title=Live blog Feb 2 - Egypt protests | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> In Cairo, many of the protesters from the previous day's protest decided to sleep and remain in Tahrir Square while more protesters came to joined them.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/02/world/middleeast/02scene.html?src=twrhp|title=Quiet Acts of Protest on a Noisy Day}}</ref>
â
During the night of 1â2 February, Mubarak supporters and anti-Mubarak protesters clashed in Alexandria; shots were reportedly fired in the air.<ref name="aljazbloglive">{{Cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/01/live-blog-feb-2-egypt-protests |title=Live blog Feb 2 - Egypt protests | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Provocateurs sent by the Egyptian government, armed with clubs, stones, rocks, swords, and pocket knives, attacked protesters in central Cairo, including Tahrir square.<ref>{{Cite news|journal=New York Times|title=Clashes Erupt in Cairo Between Mubarakâs Allies and Foes|date=2 February 2011|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/03/world/middleeast/03egypt.html|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> In Cairo, many of the protesters from the previous day's protest decided to sleep and remain in Tahrir Square while more protesters came to joined them.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/02/world/middleeast/02scene.html?src=twrhp|title=Quiet Acts of Protest on a Noisy Day}}</ref> The [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|NDP]] sent many people to show support to Hosni Mubarak.<ref>http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2045328_2045333_2045720,00.html</ref>
  â
Private [[mercenaries]] were also said to be in Egypt to evacuate foreigners.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/>
+
At noon local time, internet access in Egypt has been at least partially restored and the night-time curfew in Egypt has been eased. It will now run from 5:00 pm to 7:00 am the next day instead of 3:00 pm to 8:00 am.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12307698 |title=BBC News - Egypt unrest |publisher=BBC News |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Curfew hours were shortened to 5:00 pm to 7:00 am the next day.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/>
â
Some of the Pro-Mubarak supporters were reportedly off-duty and [[undercover]] police.<ref>{{Cite web|author=By the CNN Wire Staff |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/02/egypt.pro.mubarak/ |title=Who are the pro-Mubarak demonstrators? - CNN.com |publisher=CNN |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
+
The army was asking the protesters to go home saying "''The armed forces call on the protesters to go home for the sake of bringing back stability.''"<ref>http://news.nationalpost.com/2011/02/02/goodspeed-analysis-only-the-egyptian-army-has-power-to-restore-stability/</ref> State-television announced to the protesters "You have to evacuate Tahrir Square immediately. We've got confirmed information that violent groups are heading toward Tahrir Square carrying firebombs and seeking to burn the Square."<ref name="aljazbloglive"/>
â
Al Jazeera's live reporting showed that Mubarak supporters were carrying police IDs amidst clashes and that gunfire was heard in Tahrir Square.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/><ref name="aljazlive">''Al Jazeera English''. Breaking News. 2 February 2011. 16:00</ref>
+
The [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|NDP]] sent many people to show support to Hosni Mubarak.<ref>http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2045328_2045333_2045720,00.html</ref> Also security officials have been witnessed bribing ordinary citizens into attacking protesters.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/> Provocateurs sent by the Egyptian government, came riding on horses<ref>[http://www.elpais.com/fotogaleria/Enfrentamientos/Cairo/elpgal/20110202elpepuint_2/Zes/14 Photo gallery] - El PaÃ­s</ref> and camels<ref>[http://www.elpais.com/fotogaleria/Enfrentamientos/Cairo/elpgal/20110202elpepuint_2/Zes/13 Photo gallery] - El PaÃ­s</ref> armed with swords, whips,<ref>[http://www.wired.com/dangerroom/2011/02/horses-camels-rocks-molotovs-egypts-thug-tech/?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+WiredDangerRoom+%28Blog+-+Danger+Room%29 "Horses, Camels, Rocks, Molotovs: Egyptâs Thug Tech"] - ''Spencer Ackerman'' - Wired.com - Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Mubarak supporters, protesters clash in Egypt|author=|newspaper=msnbc.com|date=2 February 2011|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41383377/ns/world_news-mideast/n_africa/|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> clubs, stones, rocks, and pocket knives, attacked anti-government protesters in central Cairo<ref>{{Cite news|journal=New York Times|title=Clashes Erupt in Cairo Between Mubarakâs Allies and Foes|date=2 February 2011|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/03/world/middleeast/03egypt.html|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>, including Tahrir square..<ref>{{Cite video|date=2 February 2011|title=Camels & horses storm into Tahrir Square as protesters clash in Cairo|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YXwKqmDmuDs|medium=News|publisher=RussiaToday|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{YouTube|xcjJsg8AD2g|Raw Video: Dramatic New Mages of Cairo Violence }}</ref> Private [[mercenaries]] were also said to be in Egypt to evacuate foreigners.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/> Also some of the Pro-Mubarak supporters were reportedly off-duty and [[undercover]] police.<ref>{{Cite web|author=By the CNN Wire Staff |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/02/egypt.pro.mubarak/ |title=Who are the pro-Mubarak demonstrators? - CNN.com |publisher=CNN |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Al Jazeera's live reporting showed that Mubarak supporters were carrying police IDs amidst clashes and that gunfire was heard in Tahrir Square.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/><ref name="aljazlive">''Al Jazeera English''. Breaking News. 2 February 2011. 16:00</ref>
â
Pro-Mubarak supporters on horses<ref>[http://www.elpais.com/fotogaleria/Enfrentamientos/Cairo/elpgal/20110202elpepuint_2/Zes/14 Photo gallery] - El PaÃ­s</ref> and camels<ref>[http://www.elpais.com/fotogaleria/Enfrentamientos/Cairo/elpgal/20110202elpepuint_2/Zes/13 Photo gallery] - El PaÃ­s</ref> equipped with swords and whips attacked anti-government protesters<ref>[http://www.wired.com/dangerroom/2011/02/horses-camels-rocks-molotovs-egypts-thug-tech/?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+WiredDangerRoom+%28Blog+-+Danger+Room%29 "Horses, Camels, Rocks, Molotovs: Egyptâs Thug Tech"] - ''Spencer Ackerman'' - Wired.com - Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Mubarak supporters, protesters clash in Egypt|author=|newspaper=msnbc.com|date=2 February 2011|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41383377/ns/world_news-mideast/n_africa/|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> and rode into Tahrir Square.<ref>{{Cite video|date=2 February 2011|title=Camels & horses storm into Tahrir Square as protesters clash in Cairo|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YXwKqmDmuDs|medium=News|publisher=RussiaToday|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{YouTube|xcjJsg8AD2g|Raw Video: Dramatic New Mages of Cairo Violence }}</ref>
+
[[Molotov cocktails]] were also used on anti-Mubarak protesters.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20110202/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_egypt |title=Chaos in Cairo as Mubarak backers, opponents clash - Yahoo! News |publisher=News.yahoo.com |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> The Egyptian Museum was firebombed and pro-Mubarak supporters were filmed dropping stones<ref>[http://www.elpais.com/fotogaleria/Enfrentamientos/Cairo/elpgal/20110202elpepuint_2/Zes/8 Photo gallery] - El PaÃ­s</ref> and firebombs from buildings to demonstrators on the ground. Five people have been reported killed and 836 people were taken to hospitals according the Health minister of Egypt.<ref>http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/world/67633/five-dead-as-shots-fired-during-cairo-clashes</ref> There were also clashes in Alexandria.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12345656 |title=BBC News - Egypt unrest: deadly clashes rock Cairo's Tahrir Square |publisher=BBC News |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> There was also unrest in Port Said.<ref name="aljazlive"/>
â
[[Molotov cocktails]] were also used on anti-Mubarak protesters.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20110202/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_egypt |title=Chaos in Cairo as Mubarak backers, opponents clash - Yahoo! News |publisher=News.yahoo.com |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Five people have been reported killed and 836 people were taken to hospitals according the Health minister of Egypt.<ref>http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/world/67633/five-dead-as-shots-fired-during-cairo-clashes</ref>
+
[[CNN]]'s [[Anderson Cooper]] was also attacked by the pro-Mubarak group.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/02/02/anderson-cooper-attacked-punched-egypt_n_817352.html |title=Anderson Cooper Attacked, Punched In The Head By Pro-Mubarak Mob In Egypt |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> The pro-Mubarak activists also attacked [[Al Arabiya]] reporter Ahmed Bagato while he was trying to show them harassing the anti-Mubarak protesters.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/egypt/8288167/Egypt-protests-live.html |title=Egypt protests: live |publisher=Telegraph |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> The Western media has now begun to talk openly of the possibility of Egypt descending into civil war between anti-Mubarak and pro-Mubarak protesters as violence between the two sides escalates, so far leaving hundreds injured.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Egypt-Crisis-Violence-Breaks-Out-Between-Pro-And-Anti-Mubarak-Supporters-In-Tahrir-Square-Cairo/Article/201102115920969?lpos=World_News_Carousel_Region_0&lid=ARTICLE_15920969_Egypt_Crisis%3A_Violence_Breaks_Out_Between_Pro_And_Anti-Mubarak_Supporters_In_Tahrir_Square%2C_Cairo |title=Egypt Crisis: Violence Breaks Out Between Pro And Anti-Mubarak Supporters In Tahrir Square, Cairo | World News | Sky News |publisher=News.sky.com |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4023068,00.html |title=Civil war underway in Egypt?|publisher=ynetnews.com |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref>[http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/crisis-in-egypt/latest-news/hundreds-injured-one-dead-after-mubarak-protesters-and-supporters-clash/article1891913/page2/ "Hundreds injured, one dead after Mubarak protesters and supporters clash"] by Hadeel Al-Shalchi and Sarah El Deeb - Cairo, Egyptâ ''The Associated Press'' - 2 Feb. 2011 - The Globe and Mail - Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/world/story/2011/02/02/egypt-mubarak-military.html "Egyptian clashes leave 3 dead, hundreds hurt"] - Demonstrations continue in Cairo despite curfew - Wednesday, 2 February 2011 - ''CBC News'' - Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref>
â
The Egyptian Museum was firebombed and pro-Mubarak supporters were filmed dropping stones<ref>[http://www.elpais.com/fotogaleria/Enfrentamientos/Cairo/elpgal/20110202elpepuint_2/Zes/8 Photo gallery] - El PaÃ­s</ref> and firebombs from buildings to demonstrators on the ground.
+
UN Secretary General Ban-ki Moon condemned the violence and reiterated calls for reform.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE71120F20110202 |title=UPDATE 2-UN's Ban urges reform not repression in Egypt | News by Country | Reuters |publisher=Af.reuters.com |date=9 February 2009 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
  +
While EU foreign policy chief Catherine Ashton also said that the violence must stop and that Mubarak needs to be more explicit in showing the people what changes would happen.<ref name="aljazlive"/>
â
Security officials have been witnessed bribing ordinary citizens into attacking protesters.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/>
+
UK Prime Minister David Cameron and the White House condemned the violence, and the United States' State Department also called for restraint amidst the violence.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/> US President Obama also said that a transition must begin "right now."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/02/egypt-army-statement-idUSWEA517720110202 |title=Army asks Egyptians to return to normal life-TV |publisher=Reuters |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> German Foreign Minister Guido Westerwelle and French President Nicolas Sarkozy asserted the right to march peacefully, while Turkish Premier Recep Tayyip Erdogan called for an enhanced to democratisations. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu expressed concern over a new government saying: "I am convinced that that the forces that want to bring change and democratization in Egypt will also enhance peace between Israel and the Arab world. But we are not there yet. The struggle has not been decided...We need to do everything to make sure that peace endures."<ref>{{Cite web|author=Alan Silverleib |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/02/02/egypt.world.reaction/ |title=World leaders denounce attacks on Egyptian protesters |publisher=CNN |date= |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref>
â
There were also clashes in Alexandria.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12345656 |title=BBC News - Egypt unrest: deadly clashes rock Cairo's Tahrir Square |publisher=BBC News |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
There was also unrest in Port Said.<ref name="aljazlive"/>
  â   â
;Attack on the media
  â
[[CNN]]'s [[Anderson Cooper]] was also attacked by the pro-Mubarak group.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/02/02/anderson-cooper-attacked-punched-egypt_n_817352.html |title=Anderson Cooper Attacked, Punched In The Head By Pro-Mubarak Mob In Egypt |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
The pro-Mubarak activists attacked [[Al Arabiya]] reporter Ahmed Bagato while he was trying to show them harassing the anti-Mubarak protesters.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/egypt/8288167/Egypt-protests-live.html |title=Egypt protests: live |publisher=Telegraph |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
;Domestic responses
 
Mubarak rejects international calls to step aside. Finance Minister Samir Radwan said the government would be "open to discussion with all shades of political opinions". The army had earlier broadcast a message on television: ''...You began by going out to express your demands and you are the ones capable of restoring normal life.''
Mubarak rejects international calls to step aside. Finance Minister Samir Radwan said the government would be "open to discussion with all shades of political opinions". The army had earlier broadcast a message on television: ''...You began by going out to express your demands and you are the ones capable of restoring normal life.''
â
A coalition of the opposition parties agreed to hold talks with the newly formed government. However, Mohamed ElBaradei and the Muslim Brotherhood stressed they would not talk to any government representative, including Vice President Omar Suleiman, until Mubarak's resignation.<ref>http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/is-mubarak-at-the-end-of-his-tether-1.340934</ref>
+
[[Ali Gomaa]], the [[Grand Mufti]] of Egypt, says: "I greet President Mubarak who offered dialogue and responded to the demands of the people. Going against legitimacy is [[Haram|forbidding]]. This is an invitation for chaos. We support stability. What we have now is a blind chaos leading to a civil war. I call on all parents to ask their children to stay home." A former general who was a part of the intelligence services said that Mubarak would have no qualms about "setting the whole country on fire."<ref name="aljazbloglive"/>
â   â
Mohammed ElBaradei called on the army to intervene.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/> He also said Mubarak should be given a "safe exit" for Friday's "Departure Day"<ref>{{Cite web|author=John Lyons, Cairo |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/hosni-mubarak-must-go-by-friday-says-mohamed-elbaradei/story-e6frg6so-1225998404724 |title=Hosni Mubarak must go by Friday, says Mohamed ElBaradei |work=The Australian |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> and that "Today's violence is again an indication of a criminal regime that has lost any commonsense. When the regime tries to counter a peaceful demonstration by using thugs â¦ there are few words that do justice to this villainy and I think it can only hasten that regime's departure."<ref>{{Cite web|author=Staff reporters|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/02/egypt-revolution-turns-ugly|title=Egypt's revolution turns ugly as Mubarak fights back|work=The Guardian|date= 2 February 2011|accessdate= 2 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
[[Ali Gomaa]], the [[Grand Mufti]] of Egypt, says: "I greet President Mubarak who offered dialogue and responded to the demands of the people. Going against legitimacy is [[Haram|forbidding]]. This is an invitation for chaos. We support stability. What we have now is a blind chaos leading to a civil war. I call on all parents to ask their children to stay home." A former general who was a part of the intelligence services said that Mubarak would have no qualms about "setting the whole country on fire."<ref name="aljazbloglive"/>
  â   â
State-television announced at 19:21 that "You have to evacuate Tahrir Square immediately. We've got confirmed information that violent groups are heading toward Tahrir Square carrying firebombs and seeking to burn the Square."<ref name="aljazbloglive"/>
  â   â
The army was asking the protesters to go home saying "''The armed forces call on the protesters to go home for the sake of bringing back stability.''"<ref>http://news.nationalpost.com/2011/02/02/goodspeed-analysis-only-the-egyptian-army-has-power-to-restore-stability/</ref>
  â   â
;International reactions
  â
UN Secretary General Ban-ki Moon condemned the violence and reiterated calls for reform.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE71120F20110202 |title=UPDATE 2-UN's Ban urges reform not repression in Egypt | News by Country | Reuters |publisher=Af.reuters.com |date=9 February 2009 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
EU foreign policy chief Catherine Ashton also said that the violence must stop and that Mubarak needs to be more explicit in showing the people what changes would happen.<ref name="aljazlive"/>
  â   â
UK Prime Minister David Cameron and the White House condemned the violence, and the United States' State Department also called for restraint amidst the violence.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/> US President Obama also said that a transition must begin "right now."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/02/egypt-army-statement-idUSWEA517720110202 |title=Army asks Egyptians to return to normal life-TV |publisher=Reuters |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
German Foreign Minister Guido Westerwelle and French President Nicolas Sarkozy asserted the right to march peacefully, while Turkish Premier Recep Tayyip Erdogan called for an enhanced to democratisations. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu expressed concern over a new government saying: "I am convinced that that the forces that want to bring change and democratization in Egypt will also enhance peace between Israel and the Arab world. But we are not there yet. The struggle has not been decided...We need to do everything to make sure that peace endures."<ref>{{Cite web|author=Alan Silverleib |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/02/02/egypt.world.reaction/ |title=World leaders denounce attacks on Egyptian protesters |publisher=CNN |date= |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref>
  â
The Western media has now begun to talk openly of the possibility of Egypt descending into civil war between anti-Mubarak and pro-Mubarak protesters as violence between the two sides escalates, so far leaving hundreds injured.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Egypt-Crisis-Violence-Breaks-Out-Between-Pro-And-Anti-Mubarak-Supporters-In-Tahrir-Square-Cairo/Article/201102115920969?lpos=World_News_Carousel_Region_0&lid=ARTICLE_15920969_Egypt_Crisis%3A_Violence_Breaks_Out_Between_Pro_And_Anti-Mubarak_Supporters_In_Tahrir_Square%2C_Cairo |title=Egypt Crisis: Violence Breaks Out Between Pro And Anti-Mubarak Supporters In Tahrir Square, Cairo | World News | Sky News |publisher=News.sky.com |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4023068,00.html |title=Civil war underway in Egypt?|publisher=ynetnews.com |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref>[http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/crisis-in-egypt/latest-news/hundreds-injured-one-dead-after-mubarak-protesters-and-supporters-clash/article1891913/page2/ "Hundreds injured, one dead after Mubarak protesters and supporters clash"] by Hadeel Al-Shalchi and Sarah El Deeb - Cairo, Egyptâ ''The Associated Press'' - 2 Feb. 2011 - The Globe and Mail - Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/world/story/2011/02/02/egypt-mubarak-military.html "Egyptian clashes leave 3 dead, hundreds hurt"] - Demonstrations continue in Cairo despite curfew - Wednesday, 2 February 2011 - ''CBC News'' - Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref>
+
Mohammed ElBaradei called on the army to intervene.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/> He also said Mubarak should be given a "safe exit" for Friday's "Departure Day."<ref>{{Cite web|author=John Lyons, Cairo |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/hosni-mubarak-must-go-by-friday-says-mohamed-elbaradei/story-e6frg6so-1225998404724 |title=Hosni Mubarak must go by Friday, says Mohamed ElBaradei |work=The Australian |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> and that "Today's violence is again an indication of a criminal regime that has lost any commonsense. When the regime tries to counter a peaceful demonstration by using thugs â¦ there are few words that do justice to this villainy and I think it can only hasten that regime's departure."<ref>{{Cite web|author=Staff reporters|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/02/egypt-revolution-turns-ugly|title=Egypt's revolution turns ugly as Mubarak fights back|work=The Guardian|date= 2 February 2011|accessdate= 2 February 2011}}</ref> A coalition of the opposition parties agreed to hold talks with the newly formed government. However, Mohamed ElBaradei and the Muslim Brotherhood stressed they would not talk to any government representative, including Vice President Omar Suleiman, until Mubarak's resignation.<ref>http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/is-mubarak-at-the-end-of-his-tether-1.340934</ref>
==== 3 February ====
==== 3 February ====
